title: Tuesday, 23rd August, 2016

BE

11:07 am

PM

Forgot about Jackson Hole

PM

Are we expecting any fireworks this year?

11:07 am
BE

There's been some quite unsubtle guidance about the potential for a September hike

BE

Let's assume that's job done and we'll get something that is, at the margin, slightly more dovish than hawkish.

PM

If there's a September hike, why is the dollar going down

11:09 am
BE

Because it went up yesterday.

PM

Hmm

BE

And JH is not until Friday.

11:10 am
PM

Let me share some Neil Mellor

PM

BNY Mellon

PM

Mellor of Mellon

11:10 am
PM

n our commentaries last week, we highlighted how Fed cheerleading for policy normalisation had been ignored by the market with even Bill Dudley's allusions to a September hike given short shrift as the USD index plumbed the quarter's lows. However, notwithstanding the vagaries of summer markets, yesterday's price action was suggestive of a rather more cautious stance about Fed policy.

PM

Last Tuesday, Bill Dudley, the NY Fed chief said that "We're edging closer towards the point in time where it will be appropriate I think to raise interest rates further ... I think it's possible [to hike in September]". And Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart went one further, stating that "It's conceivable we could have two rate increases this year." But the market paid little heed to this and to the (admittedly rather more equivocal), minutes of the July FOMC, released on Wednesday. Yet whilst comments from Messrs Dudley and Lockhart appeared not to resonate, the market nonetheless took note of Stanley Fischer: on Sunday, the Fed vice chair informed the Aspen Institute that "We are close to our targets" before elaborating upon a fairly optimistic take on the US outlook. What Mr Fischer did not do was specify his thoughts on the timing of any policy shift; yet, the USD continued to build on what has become a familiar Friday turnaround of the previous four days' trend. Although the USD has since ceded ground, the question being pondered on the newswires was whether Mr Fischer would risk contradicting his chief just days before she takes to the podium at Jackson Hole; but then why this question was not posed by Bill Dudley's more assertive (and timing-specific) statement about policy is not really apparent. The plot is thickening ahead of what could well be one of the most important dates on the calendar this year

PM

Of course, if her colleagues' recent statements are anything to go by then the Fed chief will simply deliver a clear endorsement for a hike in rates accompanied by a rather hazy timetable; but if clarity is to be forthcoming, the Economic Symposium at Jackson Hole might well be considered a most suitable occasion to deliver it. When it comes to pivotal moments, Jackson Hole has some form: at this venue in in 2010, Ben Bernanke set the stage for QE II whilst twelve years earlier, Alan Greenspan used the meeting to flesh out an easier policy stance in the face of an intensifying emerging markets crisis. And in 2016, the stakes are perhaps as great as they have ever been. To talk of deflation is perhaps no longer en vogue, but as a student of Japan's 'lost decade', Ben Bernanke knew that when he, and his colleague Janet Yellen, were given the 'opportunity' to put his plans into action in 2009, the finishing line lay somewhere over a distant horizon and would only be recognised in hindsight. This has warranted the Fed's overt caution since 2013; but serial postponement of normalisation only serves to make a bigger rod for the Fed's back and deepen markets presumptions about the Greenspan put, with all the 'reaching for yield' and leverage that this entails.

11:11 am
PM

So the Economic Symposium at Jackson Hole may not only be pivotal in this, the ninth year in the post-crisis era, but for the crisis period as a whole. Ultimately, we remain convinced that the Fed's mettle will only be truly tested once it has taken the next one or two steps along the path towards normalisation: whether that process resumes in earnest this week remains to be seen.

PM

So Mellor \_(ツ)_/¯

11:12 am
BE

Housebuilders, then? They're moving, at least.

PM

11:13 am
BE

Though it's extending a rally from yesterday that people were pinning on this Property Week .... thing.

BE

http://www.propert...us/5084708.article

BE

The government is readying a post-Brexit vote housing package that will provide billions of pounds to residential developers in an attempt to abate the housing crisis and stimulate the flagging economy.

11:13 am
PM

(Otter -- i like the sound of an internet friends pub lunch. Let's et it up.)

BE

Autumn Statement leak, or specu-leak, about some scheme to underwrite builders.

BE

It is understood that the new multi-billion pound fund, administered through the Homes and Communities Agency (HCA), will back developers from all parts of the industry, including the private rented sector (PRS).

Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will be in pole position to receive the money, which will be made available in the form of loans, as will developers using modular construction to build out schemes.

A source familiar with the plans said the all-encompassing fund would also support the assembly of complex sites around the country, and would be used to give financial guarantees to developers worried about the risks of delivering big schemes.

The final details of the fund – which the source said would comprise new money – are currently being thrashed out at the top level of government and are likely to be announced in the Autumn Statement.

11:14 am
BE

Which looks ........... Well, the word that springs to mind is unnecessary.

BE

The housebuilders no longer lack capital, nor do they want for credit.

BE

The 2008 shakeout recapitalised the big ones and killed the small ones.

11:19 am

indeed

11:20 am

PM

Persimmon

BE

11:21 am
BE

But can't be bothered right now to retread the argument. So, Persimmon.

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 1,877, up 83 (+4.63%), High: 1,881, Low: 1,820, Volume: 940.58k
BE

Numbers are good, guidance is fine.

11:22 am
BE

As you'd expect from a company that's largely -- and perhaps temporarily -- divorced itself from economic trends by deliberate undersupply and hoarding the means of production.

BE

Here's Canaccord to summarise.

BE

Persimmon has delivered another very strong performance, highlighting its sector
leading quality. PBT at £352m is around +3.5% ahead of our forecast on a very strong
margin performance at 23.8%. (+330bps). Strong results combined with a net cash
position of £462m supports the long-term capital return strategy and dividend outlook.
The focus this morning is likely to be on the very positive comments on recent trading
and outlook into the autumn selling season. Management confirms that since 1st July,
visitor levels are up by +20% and private sale reservation rates are up by +17%. While it
is the traditionally quieter summer period, customer demand is said to be encouraging
with management anticipating a good autumn selling season. While the macro outlook
remains uncertain, today's comments from management on recent trading and outlook
into the autumn selling season are as positive and encouraging as we could have
expected. The business continues to look well positioned to pay its remaining 550p of
capital return even in a weaker overall housing market. Yield continues to look attractive
at over 6% and likely to be one of the most resilient in the sector.

11:23 am
BE

Interim Results Summary
• PBT increased by +29% to £352m, which was c.+3.5% ahead of our £340m forecast.
• As previously guided, completions were up by +6% to 7,238 with the ASP up by +6% to
£250.7k.
• Underlying operating margins were up impressively from 20.5% to 23.8%, which was
higher than our forecast of 23.1%.
• Net cash at the end of June was £462m with 7,108 plots of land being acquired in the
first half giving a land bank of 93,519. ROCE increased to 35.6%.
• Remaining 550p per share of capital return commitments look well underpinned with
management strengthening underlying the business also.
• Private sales reservation rate since 1st July are up by +17% with site visitors up by
+20%. Order book is up by +2% to £1.75bn.

BE

Shares have bounced strongly after the sharp sell-off post the Brexit vote. They are up by
+12% over the last week and up by over c.+35% from the recent lows. They reside on a
2017E P/NAV multiple of c.2.0 times versus the sector average of c.1.5 times and offer a
committed dividend yield of +6.3%.

BE

And Cazenove.

11:24 am
BE

Persimmon H1 results are modestly ahead of our expectations and market commentary is stronger than we had expected. Revenue was preannounced in July; however, we expect a strong H1 margin to drive low- to midsingle-digit upgrades to FY consensus (23.8% operating margin, vs. guidance of 23%+ and JPMe: 23.3%). H2 to date the LFL sales rate is up y/y by 17%, vs. peer commentary to date that LFLs have been broadly flat y/y (probably, in our view, driven by its lack of London exposure, coupled with the one-off effect of a large number of new launches in the period). Based on current lead indicators, the group anticipates a good autumn selling season.

BE

 Encouraging comments on current market conditions: “While the result of the EU Referendum has created increased economic uncertainty, customer interest since then has been robust with visitor numbers to our sites around 20% ahead year on year. Our private sale reservation rate since 1 July is currently 17% ahead of the same period last year. The Group is now trading through the traditionally slower summer weeks but customer demand remains encouraging and we anticipate a good autumn sales season…. After a modest increase in the week following the referendum result, cancellations have returned to normal levels and are currently running slightly lower than the same period last year. ” The group has opened 48 new sites over the summer months, which we would expect to experience higher sales rates than on established sites. This, coupled with a lack of likely London dilution, in our view, probably explains why Persimmon’s commentary is stronger than the peer group average over the last few weeks (which has generally been that sales rates are broadly flat y/y).
 The order book is currently 2% up y/y in value terms, although it’s down in volume terms by 5%, something we’d attribute to the group’s recent strategy of releasing homes for sale later in the construction process, in an attempt to improve accuracy on delivery times, and thereby improve customer satisfaction metrics.
 Recommitment to volume growth and land buying. Gross margin expected to grow again in H2: The group continues to plan to increase its build activity and productivity. The group has opened 48 new sites so far in the second half of the year and plans to open around a further c. 90 new outlets during this period. Management expects these new sites to support further improvement in gross margins in H2.
 Strong H1 cash generation: As previously announced, the group’s cash balance at H1 stood at £462.0m (2015: £278.0m). While H1 land buying was only at replacement level, we still view this as very strong performance. On first view, there do not appear to be any major one-off balance sheet effects

BE

(@roddy1234: come the revolution, squire .....)

BE

undefined
BE

Partly on the same theme, Jefferies turns slightly more positive on miners this morning.

11:33 am
BE

BHP the main upgrade.

PM

On what basis?

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,063, up 29.5 (+2.86%), High: 1,069, Low: 1,050, Volume: 2.76m
11:34 am
BE

Demand stabilised and valuations don't look awful, but only BHP is big and strong enough to be worth buying.

BE

I'll give you the gist.

BE

We had been cautious on the miners due to weak demand, ongoing supply
growth, stretched balance sheets, and a lack of FCF for most mining companies.
However, demand has stabilized, supply is declining in most cases, balance
sheets have strengthened due to FCF and asset sales, and valuations are
inexpensive. Fundamentals have clearly improved. For some miners (BHP and
FMG in particular), company-specific factors are helping as well.

11:01 am
PM

Just get out when you can

BE

(Sorry, I haven't uploaded the exhibits. You'll have to imagine them.)

BE

Demand has stabilized: While Chinese data has been mixed, mining company
management teams (Rio, BHP, Glencore, Anglo, Freeport, Vale and others) have recently
noted that demand has stabilized or is modestly improving. Leading indicators are mostly
positive, and markets are balanced. With a lack of supply growth, flat demand is good
enough to support commodity prices. We have increased several commodity price forecasts
to reflect lower supply and stable demand (Exhibit 24). We have also increased our earnings
estimates and NPV-based target prices accordingly (Exhibits 25 & 26).

11:35 am
BE

Better balance sheets: Balance sheets of leveraged miners such as Glencore and
Fortescue are improving (Exhibit 3). More deleveraging would help, but downside risk due
to too much debt has subsided in most cases. This should imply higher valuations, but
multiples have actually contracted, even with share prices up so strongly YTD.

PM

How many exhibits dow we have to imagine?

BE

About a dozen.

11:36 am
BE

They're mostly lines going up and down. The context should help inform whether the lines are going up or down.

BE

(It's amazing we get away with this every day, isn't it?)

BE

Valuations are inexpensive: On spot commodity prices, 2018 multiples are inexpensive
(Exhibit 27). Even if iron ore prices fall as we expect, multiples are still low, FCF generation
is strong, and balance sheets are manageable (Exhibit 3). We expect the major miners (Rio
and BHP especially) to increase capital returns to shareholders over the next 2+ years.

11:36 am
BE

Upgrades due to company-specific factors: We upgrade BHP ('18 EV/EBITDA of 5.0x,
FCF yield of 9.5%) from Hold to Buy on valuation, commodity exposure (iron ore lump and
met coal), and better than expected free cash flow growth potential. We upgrade FMG ('18
EV/EBITDA of 6.2x, net debt/EBITDA of 1.4x, FCF yield of 15.5%) from Underperform to Hold
on balance sheet improvements, strong FCF and valuation.

BE

Sector wise .....

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,438, up 51.5 (+2.16%), High: 2,455, Low: 2,400, Volume: 789.50k
11:37 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 555.00, up 10 (+1.83%), High: 558.50, Low: 548.00, Volume: 648.52k
Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 1,835, up 10 (+0.55%), High: 1,872, Low: 1,830, Volume: 189.56k
BE

Rally. Dollar. Etc.

11:37 am
undefined
PM

William Hill?

PM

Did you mention this Morgan Stanley stuff yesterday?

11:38 am
PM

BE

Nope, yesterday was Barclays.

PM

ah, right

11:38 am
BE

Barclays said "it's only 13 times earnings and look at the recovery potential"

BE

Today, Morgan Stanley says, "but look at the bear case and it's still 13 times earnings"

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 329.67, up 4.67 (+1.44%), High: 329.70, Low: 323.00, Volume: 907.40k
11:39 am
PM

Yeah, who were MS working for in the non-bid?

PM

Cant recall immediately

BE

Ditto. Though I'm sure someone on the right can help remind us.

11:39 am
PM

But they've gone all buzzfeed on 888 -- so that probably answers my question

PM

8 Reasons to Buy 888

PM

Here are those 8 reasons, in two chunks

11:41 am
PM

1. Strong and accelerating organic revenue growth. LfL revenue growth was 12% in 2015 – this accelerated to 23% in Q4 and 20%+ growth continued in Q1 2016, driven by regulated markets and mobile.

2. Potential upside from Sports. We estimate sports revenue was c.$30m in 2015 but is growing at 50%+ per year.

3. Improving earnings quality and reducing risks. Regulated revenues reached 59% of revenues in 2015, from 55% in 2014, or two-thirds including Germany.

4. Strong and improving cash generation. FCF of $72m (after c.$15m of exceptional M&A costs) amounted to 90% of EBITDA and a FCF yield of 7.1% (trailing). We estimate that 888 could retire all of its equity within 8 years using its free cash flow. It has a strong record of cash returns, with a total dividend of 15.5c in 2015, a yield of 5.5%.

PM

5. M&A option value. In the past two years, 888 agreed to be acquired by William Hill, then to acquire bwin.party, and proposed to acquire Rank and William Hill. With its strong technology, CRM, content and brands, we view 888 as a highly attractive and scarce asset in a consolidating industry.

6. Free option in the USA. 888 is the only operator that is licensed and operating in all three US states that have legal online gambling. As further states legalise, we see a significant free option here.

7. Strong long-term track record. Revenue has grown at a 14% CAGR, and EBITDA at 19% CAGR in the last 10 years, without it issuing any equity or taking on debt, and during a period with cumulative dividends of 85c, or 31% of its current market cap.

8. Attractive valuation. Trading on a 2017e P/E of 14.7x and EV/EBITDA of 8.2x, the shares are at the lower end of the group. We think this fails to reflect the combination of attractions and growth profile.

PM

Stock;s up a tad at 217p.

11:42 am
BE

I'd not value an option on the US at any more than free, to be honest. US legalisation has been the dampest of squibs over the past decade.

BE

Also, I really try to understand 888's unregulated business, as I try to understand all bookies with unregulated businesses. And I can't understand why it's valued at what it is currently, against what it was valued previously.

BE

Particularly since nothing's changed between those two points.

11:43 am
BE

But anyway, here's Morgan Stanley on William Hill

BE

Which is a solid bit of work.

BE

William Hill rejected a 394p bid from a consortium of Rank and 888. We estimate that the deal could have been worth c.ú5 per share in time, given the planned ú100m cost synergies, upside potential from revenue synergies, and the strategic attraction of addressing William Hill's technology and management gap. We think rejection of the combination leaves William Hill in a challenging position, with a lengthy, complicated technology plan ahead of it in an increasingly challenging and competitive market, and with, as yet, no permanent CEO. William Hill's long-term track record (EBIT broadly flat over the last decade despite ú1.7bn in cumulative capex) may not inspire confidence. The significant challenges facing the internal turnaround suggest downside risk to forecasts, while the overhang of regulatory pressure on betting shop machines appears likely to limit the scope for any significant re-rating of the shares. Despite these challenges, we think the low valuation (2017e FCF yield of 8.9%), ongoing share buybacks (ú60m of the planned ú200m completed) and ongoing industry M&A are likely to provide some downside support to the shares in the short term. In the medium term, any adverse regulatory or duty changes could undermine the valuation support, suggesting c.50%
downside to our Bear Case.

11:44 am
BE

(ú = £ ... Not sure why that happened.)

BE

Not all bad news. While William Hill's growth profile has been poor, it is highly cash generative, has a strong and historic brand, a significant Retail and Online footprint and customer base, and a strong balance sheet with scope for increased leverage. Our 500p Bull Case suggests 59% upside potential, and assumes a successful turnaround of the Online division, strong growth in the USA and Australia, and stable profits per shop in Retail driven by continued high UK employment levels and no regulatory or duty changes, with ongoing share buybacks supporting a re-rating to 16x 2017e P/E, at the top end of its historic range.

BE

Economic and regulatory risks suggest significant downside risk. Our 155p Bear Case assumes regulatory setbacks for machines in Retail, leading to a 30% drop in revenue per machine, taking profit per shop to c.ú50k, broadly in-line with Ladbrokes' levels of profitability. We assume Online profits remain stagnant, with challenges developing the new Openbet platform, with inefficient marketing and CRM leading to ongoing market share losses in the key UK market. With weak trading trends, our Bear Case assumes a de-rating to under 11x P/E, at the lower end of its historic range.

11:45 am
BE

Trading on 13.2x 2017e P/E, the shares are at the higher end of their long-term average.
William Hill expects EBIT of around ú280m this year, broadly in line with its profits 10 years ago, having invested cumulative capex of ú1.7bn over the period. The poor returns reflect its lack of competitive strength in the key online channel, which is delivering all of the growth in the UK gambling industry. We see downside risks to forecasts in the next two years and resume at Underweight, but the company's ongoing share buyback plan (ú140m of the planned ú200m to complete) and ongoing industry M&A are likely to provide some downside support to the shares.

BE

Good chart also, though built on some rather big assumptions.

BE

11:46 am
BE

As in, William Hill falls to the smallest of the big online operators next year and never recovers.

BE

That's pinned on William Hill making a mess of the total system rebuild it's doing at the moment.

BE

Which, experience says, it probably will.

11:46 am
BE

Look at that Ladbrokes line for an example of how much a system migration can screw you up.

BE

As for recent speculation around follow-on bidders for William Hill ........ nah.

BE

Looks like stale bulls and random stabbings in the dark.

11:48 am
undefined
BE

What else do we have? Did you see the Swiss watch export data today?

BE

It's amazingly bad. Really, really, really bad.

11:49 am
PM

Yeah, Gary Paulin still saying sell Swatch

BE

Headline exports for July down 14% year on year.

PM

sheesh

11:49 am
BE

That's against a year-ago drop of 9%.

PM

They should advertise more

BE

lightbulb

11:50 am
BE

All regions down. This isn't a Hong Kong problem.

BE

Though it's also a Hong Kong problem. HK exports down -- get this! -- 33%!

PM

Blimey

11:51 am
BE

And July 2015 was down 29% so the comparison number was weak anyway.

BE

Quick line from Cazenove on this.

PM

I had no idea the fall was this dramatic

11:51 am
BE

The more bullish investors would argue that this might
include some inventory buybacks but only Richemont is resorting to
inventory buybacks – its key peers: Swatch, Rolex or Patek have not. In
addition, we don’t think Swiss watch exports include inventory
buybacks (they are exports, not a net of exports and imports back). We
are often asked by investors where does the bloodbath stop in HK for the
watch industry. We note that HK YTD, after a 43% correction in value
terms in the last two years, retains its number 1 market share worldwide,
12% of global Swiss watch exports. We would argue that this number
probably needs to be rebased closer to HSD contribution.

BE

Actually, let me go through Caz's regional breakdown. It's bleak. Really bleak.

BE

2) China was
down 6% yoy. In the sea of other markets being down double digit this
may go unnoticed. Indeed, China does not even feature in the short text
from the Swiss watch exports release. But this is far weaker than could
have been hoped for, in our view. For a start, compares were VERY easy
and 30 points easier than in May. In addition, China has shown some
better and positive numbers across the luxury sector in recent reporting
as China benefits from a transfer of tourists back home and tighter
customs checks and higher cross-border customs duties since April
(particularly acute on watches). We note that there has historically been a
lot of volatility on a monthly basis by countries and Swiss watch exports
are a sell in not sell out data. We hence don’t see it as wise to call this
out unduly at this stage. But still, we think it fair to acknowledge that this
was not a good outcome for China in July for Swiss watch exports and
something to monitor. South Korea was the only key country in positive
territory in Asia in July at +26% recovering post MERS.

11:52 am
BE

Europe was under significant pressure, penalised by the drain in
tourists spend. France and Germany were down 28% and 24%
respectively. Note that Spain which some investors believe may be
benefiting from a tourist transfer was also down markedly (-27%). The
only slight positive highlights were Italy (+10%) and the UK (+13%) but
both were flattered by easy compares last year. We would think the UK
increase might sustain in coming months though (beyond compares) as
TP retailers order in light of higher tourist spend buoyed by the GBP.
Italy is a less convincing growth in our view; significantly weaker tourist
data suggest this restocking should come to an end soon unless grey
market activities are fueling this.

BE

· The US was down 15% yoy or sequentially worse than in May (-9%) on
similar compares. South America was also down sharply this month
-26%, a clear deterioration on the YTD trend (-16%).

· By price points, all price points were down double digit or close to it in
value terms. Watches above SF3000 and below SF200 were impacted the
most, both down 16% yoy. Overall, units were down more than value
(-16% vs -14% respectively); this does not, however, mean that the
watch industry has resumed with pricing power, units are dragged down
by the size and decline of the less than SF200 segment (down 20% in
volume terms)

BE

What's happening here?

11:54 am
PM

Flash watches are going out of fashion, that's what's happening

BE

Honestly -- open question, readers. I imagine you're more likely than me to invest a few £K in a wristweight.

PM

And the Apple watch is slowly picking up fans

11:54 am
PM

Surprising as that may sound

BE

I really, really doubt this is Apple Watch related.

PM

hmm

11:54 am
BE

Most people I know with an Apple watch never wear it.

BE

I don't deny that they're selling. I deny they're being used.

PM

I think they are catching on -- amongst americans in particular

11:55 am
PM

But whatever

BE

Ah. Americans ....

BE

(@Otter: hipster.)

11:55 am
undefined
BE

Nearly done. Few more things to mention.

BE

BE

And Barclays.

BE

Our view: A bigger resource number from a junior partner is always likely to be taken with a pinch of salt by investors, and we do not believe the new 641mmbbl P50 estimate for the SNE discovery provided by FAR (36% ahead of Cairn’s own new estimate) will be viewed any differently. However, it does provide some support for the view that the scale of the SNE discovery can grow through further appraisal. We also consider FAR’s pursuit of pre-emption rights related to the ConocoPhillips-Woodside transaction on the asset as a minor distraction, with Cairn Energy unlikely to exercise its own pre-emption rights. We remain Overweight on Cairn with a 280p price target.

BE

Big field getting bigger: Australian-listed FAR Limited has a 15% stake in the SNE discovery, offshore Senegal, and has disclosed a new independent resource report for the discovery, increasing the gross P50 estimate by 14% to 641mmbbls. The increase reflects the most recent well results and reinstates the clear water between FAR’s resource figures and those of Cairn Energy – Cairn published a more conservative P50 resource estimate of 473mmbbls only last week. We believe the variance in estimates is likely to be attributable to differing opinions on the likely recovery factors for the field, with further appraisal and flow testing needed to refine the JV estimates ahead of a development plan submission.

Our 90p/share risked valuation of Cairn’s 40% stake is based on the 473mmbbl gross resource estimate provided by Cairn as operator. We estimate applying the new FAR resource estimate would add 24p/share (27%) to our valuation of the asset and our 281p/share Cairn Energy Tangible NAV, all else being equal.

Pre-emption still a distraction for FAR: FAR has also announced that it has confirmation from ConocoPhillips that FAR has the right to pre-empt on the agreed sale of Conoco’s 35% stake to Woodside for $430m cash. This implies FAR may be looking at options to pre-empt the deal.

Market tightness, primarily due to a lack of supply: Mining capex has fallen by 70%
from the 2012 peak, and a lack of investment combined with mine closures and depletion
has led to declining supply for most mined commodities (Exhibit 6). Iron ore and copper
are the exceptions, but the end of supply growth in both cases is in sight (Exhibits 7 & 10).
